perturbation.original_text: Distributor shall begin such distribution within [ * ] following Google's request.
perturbation.changed_text: Distributor shall begin such distribution within 1 day following Google's request.
perturbation.explanation: This modification shortens the timeframe for the distributor to begin distributing the latest version of the Distribution Products following Google's request. This might conflict with reasonable notice and preparation time, depending on the scale of distribution and the changes in the new version.
perturbation.law_explanation: Although this contract is between two companies, any employees of the distributor that are required to make changes within one day may be required to spend money to make this change (buy new software, equipment, etc.). By shortening the time to one day, the employee may not have time to request and receive reimbursement. CA Labor Code § 2802 requires employers to indemnify employees for all necessary expenditures or losses incurred in direct consequence of the discharge of their duties.

perturbation.original_text: Google may also withhold and offset against its payment obligations under this Agreement, or require Distributor to pay to Google within [ * ] of any invoice, any amounts Google [ * ] overpaid to Distributor in prior periods.
perturbation.changed_text: Google may also withhold and offset against its payment obligations under this Agreement, or require Distributor to pay to Google within 5 days of any invoice, any amounts Google overpaid to Distributor in prior periods.
perturbation.explanation: The modification reduces the timeframe for the distributor to repay any overpaid amounts to Google. This might conflict with standard accounting practices and payment processing timelines, potentially causing financial strain.
perturbation.law_explanation: Although this section refers to credit card billing, the principle of allowing a reasonable time to dispute and resolve billing errors is generally applicable. Requiring repayment within 5 days does not provide the distributor with enough time to properly audit and dispute any overpayment claims. This timeline contradicts the principle of fair billing practices as it does not allow reasonable time to investigate and resolve discrepancies, potentially mirroring the issues addressed in 15 U.S. Code § 1666b concerning credit billing disputes.

perturbation.original_text: If a period of Special Suspension extends for more than [ * ] may then terminate this Agreement (in part) in respect of the affected country or territory only, such termination to take effect upon written notice[ * ].
perturbation.changed_text: If a period of Special Suspension extends for more than 1 day may then terminate this Agreement (in part) in respect of the affected country or territory only, such termination to take effect upon written notice.
perturbation.explanation: This modification drastically reduces the time a party must wait during a 'Special Suspension' before terminating the agreement, potentially conflicting with reasonable contract law principles related to good faith and fair dealing, and opportunity to cure.
perturbation.law_explanation: Although 11 U.S. Code § 365(e)(1) relates to bankruptcy and executory contracts, it highlights the unenforceability of clauses that allow termination based solely on conditions that arise due to financial distress or similar events. By reducing the suspension period to 1 day, it effectively allows termination based on a short-term external factor (the 'Special Suspension'), undermining principles of contract stability and fair opportunity to resolve issues, analogous to the restrictions imposed in bankruptcy law. The short period doesn't allow for a reasonable cure or negotiation period, thus potentially violating good faith principles.
